title: 114_hr3295
content:
The Department of Justice is appropriated $140,000,000 for State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance, including funds for various programs like the Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant program, Drug Courts, mental health courts, programs to reduce gun crime and gang violence, and veterans treatment courts. The additional $10,000,000 for Juvenile Justice Programs is allocated for community-based violence prevention initiatives, specifically focusing on public health approaches to reducing shootings and violence. This funding is separate from the State and Local Law Enforcement Assistance budget, which includes programs like Drug Courts and veterans treatment courts. $30,000,000 additional funding for Community Oriented Policing Services Programs, with $15,000,000 for State law enforcement agencies in high-seizure States for precursor chemicals and methamphetamine, and $15,000,000 for statewide law enforcement agencies in high opioid admission States for heroin and opioid investigations. INDEPENDENT AGENCIES

Small Business Administration: $4,000,000 for entrepreneurial development programs and $1,000,000 for business loans program account.

DEPARTMENT OF LABOR

Employment and Training Administration: $265,000,000 for training and employment services.

DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES

Health Resources and Services Administration: $50,000,000 for maternal and child health under the Healthy Start Initiative. The Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration receives $10,000,000 for drug court grants. The Department of Housing and Urban Development receives $170,000,000 for the Choice Neighborhoods Initiative. The Community Planning and Development fund includes a transfer of funds. $500,000,000 is allocated for the Community Development Fund until September 30, 2016, to aid in emergency response, recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in areas affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Funds will be granted to distressed communities based on specific criteria determined by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The allocated $500,000,000 for the Community Development Fund aims to assist distressed communities affected by violence or civil unrest in 2015. Grantees must submit a plan for fund usage approval by the Secretary, focusing on long-term recovery, infrastructure restoration, and economic revitalization in impacted areas. Criteria for plan approval will be specified within 45 days of the Act's enactment, with disapproval for plans not meeting the criteria. These funds are separate from non-emergency formula allocations under the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. The Secretary will provide grantees with training on grant management, including contracts and subrecipient agreements. Performance requirements and penalties must be included in these agreements. The Secretary has the authority to waive or specify alternative requirements for statutes or regulations, except for certain provisions related to fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and the environment. Up to 30 percent of the funds can be used to supplement existing agreements. The funds are allocated for immediate community response, recovery, and revitalization assistance. Up to $10,000,000 can be transferred for necessary costs of administering and overseeing the funds. The Office of Lead Hazard Control and Healthy Homes receives an additional $30,000,000 for lead hazard reduction until September 30, 2016. General provisions include moving-to-work initiatives. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will extend Moving-to-Work agreements for designated agencies until fiscal year 2028, with certain conditions. Agencies must report financial data for policy evaluation. The Act provides emergency funding designated by Congress, subject to the President's approval. It is named the "Rebuilding Urban Inner Cities Is Long Overdue Act of 2015" or the "REBUILD Act."
